Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.raw_text: Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1984) (discussing tenant remedies for housing defects)
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: Cases (illustrative and persuasive authority recognizing landlord duty and covenant of quiet enjoyment or habitability principles)
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly adopts and elaborates a landlord’s implied warranty of habitability in residential leases, treating the lease as a contract with mutual covenants to provide habitable premises and pay rent. It discusses the landlord’s duty to maintain “safe, clean and fit” premises, the tenant’s remedies (damages, rent withholding, repair-and-deduct), and displaces constructive eviction as the primary mechanism, thereby serving as strong illustrative and persuasive authority on landlord duties and habitability principles. Although it focuses on habitability rather than using the term ‘quiet enjoyment,’ it clearly supports the broader proposition on landlord duties in residential tenancies.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: “Therefore, we now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease, whether oral or written, that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation…. Because we hold that the lease of a residential dwelling creates a contractual relationship between the landlord and tenant, the standard contract remedies of rescission, reformation and damages are available to the tenant when suing for breach of the implied warranty of habitability.”
